english_translation: Narrated by Ali: When during Umar's rule a pregnant woman was brought to him, accused of adultery. Umar asked her and she confessed. Umar ordered her to be stoned, but Ali ibn Abi Talib met her and said: What is wrong with this woman? They said: Umar ordered her to be stoned. Ali said to Umar: Did you command that she be stoned? He said: Yes, she confessed to me for adultery. Ali said: This is your authority over her, what is your authority over what is in her belly? Amir al-Mu'minin said: I did not know she was pregnant. Ali said: If you did not know, then establish a waiting period for her. Then he said: Or did you perhaps frighten her or terrify her? He said: That may have happened. Ali said: Did you not hear the Messenger of Allah ﷺ saying: There is no punishment upon one who confesses after coercion, for whoever you bind, imprison, or threaten, there is no confession from them? So Umar released her. Then he said: Women have failed to give birth to one like Ali ibn Abi Talib. If not for Ali, Umar would have perished.

english_translation: Narrated by Ali: He said: For a life, the diyyah is in four portions - one quarter aged yearlings, one quarter in their third year, one quarter young females that have not borne, one quarter females in their second year. For the tongue if uprooted, the diyyah in four portions. For the nose if uprooted or its tip cut, the diyyah in four portions - one quarter aged yearlings, one quarter in their third year, one quarter young females that have not borne, one quarter females in their second year. For the penis if uprooted, the diyyah in four portions. For the glans the diyyah in four portions. For the eye, half the diyyah. For the ear, half the diyyah. For the hand, half the diyyah. For the foot, half the diyyah. For one of the front two teeth, half the diyyah. For one of the lips, half the diyyah. For the skull wound, one third the diyyah. For the penetrating wound, one third the diyyah. For the bone-breaking fracture, fifteen camels. For the bone-crushing fracture, ten camels. For the surface wound, five camels. For the teeth, for each tooth five camels. For the fingers, for each finger ten camels. All of that is upon the aqilah (relatives who bear diyyah), and whatever is less than the tooth in the surface wound, the aqilah does not pay for it.
